Japan is an Asian nation inhabited by a race of people who
a century ago were living in, and conditioned by, an
agrarian economy which had remained unchanged through
centuries. Then came the Meiji miracle — and railroads,
spinning mills, shipyards, modern armaments, big business,
parliamentary government, hydro-electric plants, diplomacy,
exports and imports, a growing bureaucracy, and the
Westerners with their new ideas.
Almost overnight, as the
progress of nations is measured, everything changed. Every¬
thing, that is, except the people of Japan, who continued
to order their lives in accordance with 17th century
notions, traditions and beliefs even as they tended 20th
century machines and by their energies transformed this nation
from a primitive agricultural economy into a world power.
While this country lags behind the West in some aspects
of government and social consciousness and technical skills,
it has on the other hand retained enough of the former
